questions.question: Which of the following drugs is not metabolized by plasma esterases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cocaine Explanation: Cocaine is metabolized by hepatic carboxylesterase Amino Ester Local Anesthetic Metabolism Allergy Potential Procaine Metabolized by plasma esterases Aminoester causes more allergies in comparison to aminoamides since they are derivatives of p-aminobenzoic acid (allergenic) Chloroprocaine Metabolized by plasma esterases Tetracaine Metabolized by plasma esterases Cocaine Metabolized predominantly by hepatic carboxylesterase Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 865, 875, 886

questions.question: Patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being planned for a dental extraction procedure. Which of the following local anesthetic can be safely administered in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Articaine Explanation: All the following drugs (in options) belong to Aminoamides group of local anesthetics. All aminoamides undergo Enzymatic degradation in Liver except Articaine - undergoes metabolism by Plasma cholinesterase. In a patient with Liver disease, aminoamide that can be safely administered is Articaine, which is also usually preferred for short dental procedures. Aminoesters & Aminoamides: Aminoesters (1 “i” in names) Aminoamides (2 “i” in names) Drugs Procaine Chloroprocaine Tetracaine Cocaine Lidocaine Mepivacaine Prilocaine Bupivacaine Ropivacaine Duration of action & stability Short; stable Long; unstable in solution Metabolism Plasma cholinesterase Exception: Cocaine (metabolized in liver) Enzymatic degradation in Liver Exception: Articaine (undergoes metabolism by plasma cholinesterase) Metabolism rate Rapidly metabolized: Chloroprocaine Rapidly metabolized rate: Lignocaine > Mepivacaine > Bupivacaine Allergic potential Maximum with Prilocaine and Benzocaine - Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 875, 883.

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of the given drug?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Blocks Na+ channels Explanation: Image shown is Bupivacaine , a local anesthetic. All local anesthetic acts by inhibiting Na+ channels. Mechanism of action & absorption: Site: acts on nodes of ranvier Blocks transmission of pain impulse from nociceptor to spinal cord. Acts on intracellular side of Na channels at inactivation gate blocking the channel. LA doesn’t affect RMP of nerves. Blocks inactivation gates of Na+ channels → Disrupts depolarisation → No action potential generated → No pain sensation. Highest systemic absorption (routes of administration): IV route >Tracheal > Intercostal > Brachial plexus > Epidural. Form for onset of LA action (to reach target nerve) - Unionized form. Active form at site of block of Na channels- Ionized form. Higher doses will act for longer duration and lower doses for a relatively shorter duration. Duration of onset for different local anesthetics (infiltration anesthesia): Short Duration Procaine Chloroprocaine Moderate Duration Lidocaine Prilocaine Long Duration Bupivacaine Ropivacaine Shortest acting - Chloroprocaine Longest

questions.question: All among the following are true about adding Adrenaline with Lignocaine except:

options.C: Contraindicated in patients with cardiovascular disease
options.D: Increases the rate of systemic absorption

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Increases the rate of systemic absorption Explanation: Adding Adrenaline (Epinephrine) with Lignocaine decreases the rate of systemic absorption of Lignocaine and thereby decreases the effects of systemic toxicity of Lignocaine. Additives of Local Anesthetics: Epinephrine Effects: Increases the duration of action (Option A) Decreases the rate of systemic absorption (Option D) Decreases toxicity Decreases blood loss (Option B) Increases the risk of arrhythmia (increases peripheral vascular resistance) Contraindication: Hypertension, Ischaemic heart disease/ cardiovascular diseases (Option C) Can be added with most of the local anesthetics except a few eg. Ropivacaine Alternative: Felypressin - no increase in heart rate and blood pressure Alkalinization By adding Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) - increases the speed of onset.By increasing unionized form of LA which reaches the target quickly. Opioids All opioids can be added safely, exception: Remifentanil Commonly used: Fentanyl, Alfentanil, Sufentanil Can be added with most of the local anesthetics, exception: Chloroprocaine Action: synergistic analgesia Side effects: Respiratory depression, most common - pruritus α 2-adrenergic agonists Action: synergistic analgesia (in peripheral administration) ; additive effect (in systemic administration) Commonly used: Clonidine Steroids Effect: prolongs the duration of action Commonly used: Dexamethasone Reference: Barash Clinical Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 1690-1694.

questions.question: Patient following an RTA presented with multiple lacerations over the forearm and knee regions, which were sutured under LA. Few minutes after suturing, he complained of lightheadedness and dizziness, which was followed by an episode of seizure. On examination, his vitals were: HR-58 bpm; BP-88/50mmHg. What is the definitive management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Give 20% intralipid cardiac solution Explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of Local anesthetic associated Systemic toxicity (LAST) that has led to CNS (dizziness, seizures) and cardiac effects (bradycardia, hypotension. The definitive management would be to administer 20% intralipid solution . Although other options: Administer IV Lorazepam (Option B) and Airway management (Option D) is also a part of management protocol, but is not the definitive management in this case. Perform Urgent CT Head (Option A) is not required at this stage as there is no history of trauma to the head and the symptoms started a few minutes after administration of local anesthesia. Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST): Clinical Features CNS effects: Early and less severe. First symptom: circumoral paraesthesia First sign: nystagmus At low plasma concentration: mild sensory disturbances. Increased concentration: CNS excitation, seizure activity. Higher concentration: CNS depression, coma, respiratory depression, arrest. Cardiac effects: Usually late but severe form of toxicity, may lead to death. Hypotension, dysrhythmias, myocardial depression. Potent agents (bupivacaine, ropivacaine, levobupivacaine) linked to cardiovascular collapse, heart block. Safety profile Bupivacaine has more risk to cause LAST than Lidocaine Most potent highly lipid soluble drugs are more likely to cause Prevention Risk recognition and dose reduction. Careful aspiration before injection. Incremental administration (3-5 mL) with continuous heart rate monitoring. Use ultrasonographic guidance to confirm anesthetic deposit. Use a vasoactive agent like epinephrine to reduce systemic absorption and serve as an intravascular indicator. Treatment Recognize LAST (Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity) early and call for help. Airway management: Secure airway, ventilate with 100% oxygen. Administer 20% Lipid Emulsion: (Option C) Bolus: 1.5 mL/kg over 2-3 min. Infusion: at 0.25 mL/kg/min-0.5ml/kg/min for 15-20 mins Maximum initial dose: 12 ml/kg Administration of antiepileptics: for seizure control, benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam is preferred. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: if necessary, monitor the patient at least for initial 2-6 hours following resuscitation. Reference: Barash Clinical Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 1706-1721

questions.question: Anesthetist decides to administer Lignocaine with adrenaline for epidural analgesia. Choose the correct pair of concentration of Lignocaine and the concentration ratio when used with adrenaline.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 1% - 1:200,000 Explanation: Ideal concentration of Lignocaine when given epidurally is 1-2% and the concentration ratio with Adrenaline for Lignocaine/Bupivacaine/Prilocaine is 1:200,000 . Concentrations of Lignocaine: Route of administration Concentration Intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) 0.5% Nerve blocks Minor block: 1% Major block: 1% Epidural 1-2% (Option B) Topical Solution: 2-4% EMLA: 2.5% Aerosol/suppository: 10% Spinal 5% Concentration of adrenaline (epinephrine): Anaphylactic shock 1:1000 IM 0.5 mg IM or SC Cardiac arrest 1:10,000 IV 1mg IV Local anesthetic 1:200,000 (Option B) Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 878-882

questions.question: Cocaine exerts its local anesthetic action by blocking which ion channel?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sodium channels Explanation: Cocaine blocks sodium channels , which inhibits the propagation of action potentials in nerve cells, producing its local anesthetic effect. Cocaine : Classification : Ester local anesthetic and CNS stimulant. Mechanism of Action: Blocks sodium channels to inhibit nerve impulses and inhibits reuptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin, resulting in CNS stimulant effects. Medical Use: Used for topical anesthesia especially due to its vasoconstrictive properties. Vasoconstriction : Causes vasoconstriction, which helps reduce bleeding and prolong anesthesia during procedures. Duration of Action: Short half life (approx. 1 hour) Metabolism : Metabolized predominantly by hepatic carboxylesterase. CNS Effects: Acts as a strong CNS stimulant, leading to euphoria, increased energy, and potential addiction. Side Effects: Includes hypertension, tachycardia, arrhythmias, seizures, and addiction. Contraindications : Contraindicated in patients with heart disease, hypertension, and seizure disorders because of its cardiovascular and CNS stimulant properties. Chloroprocaine Classification : Ester local anesthetic. Mechanism of Action: Blocks sodium channels, preventing the propagation of nerve impulses to produce local anesthesia. Primarily used for local, epidural, and spinal anesthesia, especially in obstetric procedures(labor and delivery). No Vasoconstriction Duration of Action: Short duration of action due to rapid metabolism by plasma cholinesterase, making it ideal for short surgical procedures. Metabolism : Metabolized quickly by plasma cholinesterase, resulting in a lower risk of systemic toxicity. CNS Effects: Lacks CNS stimulant properties and does not cause euphoria or have any potential for addiction. Side Effects: Generally well-tolerated; possible side effects include allergic reactions due to its ester structure. Minimal systemic effects. Contraindications : Contraindicated in patients allergic to ester-type local anesthetics. Reference: Cocaine Chloroprocaine

questions.question: What is the major concern associated with bupivacaine toxicity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cardiotoxicity Explanation: Bupivacaine is known for its potential cardiotoxic effects , particularly when administered in high doses or if accidentally injected into a blood vessel, which can lead to severe cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest. Bupivacaine Classification Bupivacaine is an amide-type local anesthetic Mechanism of Action It works by blocking sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing the propagation of nerve impulses, which results in local anesthesia. Clinical Uses Commonly used for spinal, epidural, and peripheral nerve blocks. Widely used in labor and delivery for epidural anesthesia and in long-duration surgeries. Duration of Action Longer duration of action compared to other local anesthetics like lidocaine. It can provide anesthesia for several hours, making it ideal for prolonged procedures. Onset of Action Has a slower onset (10-15 minutes) compared to faster-acting anesthetics like lidocaine. Cardiotoxicity Major concern with bupivacaine is its potential for cardiotoxicity, especially at higher doses or when inadvertently injected intravenously, leading to severe arrhythmias or cardiac arrest. Metabolism Metabolized primarily in the liver by cytochrome P450 enzymes and excreted by the kidneys. Enantiomers The S-enantiomer of bupivacaine, known as levobupivacaine, is associated with reduced cardiotoxicity and is often used as a safer alternative. Lipid Solubility & Protein Binding Bupivacaine has high lipid solubility and high protein binding, which contributes to its prolonged duration of action. Contraindications Should be avoided in patients with severe cardiac arrhythmias, and caution should be used in patients with liver disease due to its hepatic metabolism. Common Side Effects In addition to cardiotoxicity, other potential side effects include CNS toxicity, such as dizziness, seizures, and lightheadedness, especially with accidental intravascular injection. Toxicity Direct intravenous injection or rapid vascular uptake of the drug is the most common reason for bupivacaine toxicity, which has an upper limit of 2.5 to 3.5 mg/kg upper limit of dosing. Treatment for toxicity: 20% intralipid solution. Reference: Bupivacaine

questions.question: What is the primary function of pseudocholinesterase?

options.A: Breaks down acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions
options.B: Hydrolyzes ester-based compounds in the plasma
options.C: Converts succinylcholine into its active form

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hydrolyzes ester-based compounds in the plasma Explanation : Pseudocholinesterase plays a critical role in metabolizing ester-based local anesthetics (chloroprocaine, procaine, tetracaine) and neuromuscular blocking agents (succinylcholine, mivacurium). Pseudocholinesterases : Serine hydrolase enzyme primarily produced in the liver that catalyzes the hydrolysis of choline esters. Drugs Metabolized by Pseudocholinesterase Succinylcholine Use : Neuromuscular blocking agent (commonly used for rapid sequence intubation or short surgical procedures). Mechanism : Succinylcholine is hydrolyzed by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma. Mivacurium Use : Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Mechanism : Mivacurium, like succinylcholine, is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. Chloroprocaine Use : Local anesthetic (commonly used in obstetric anesthesia). Mechanism : Chloroprocaine is an ester local anesthetic rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. Procaine Use : Local anesthetic (used in dental procedures and minor surgeries). Mechanism : Procaine, another ester-type local anesthetic, is hydrolyzed by pseudocholinesterase into para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and diethylaminoethanol. Tetracaine Use : Local anesthetic (used in spinal and topical anesthesia). Mechanism : Tetracaine is also an ester local anesthetic metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. Breaks down acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions (Option A) :This function is carried out by acetylcholinesterase. Converts succinylcholine into its active form (Option C): Pseudocholinesterase breaks down succinylcholine, rather than activating it. Metabolizes amide local anesthetics (Option D): Amide local anesthetics (like lidocaine) are metabolized by the liver, not by pseudocholinesterase. Reference: Pseudocholinesterases Dibucaine number test

questions.question: In comparison to the retrobulbar block, which statement is true regarding the peribulbar block?

options.A: It is performed deeper than the retrobulbar block.
options.B: It has a higher risk of optic nerve injury.
options.C: It generally provides a wider area of anesthesia.
options.D: It is more likely to cause complications compared to the retrobulbar block.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It generally provides a wider area of anesthesia. Explanation: Peribulbar block provides a wider area of anesthesia. Aspect Retrobulbar Block Peribulbar Block Anatomical Location Behind the globe within the orbit Around the globe, in the peribulbar space Depth of Injection Deeper (often near the optic nerve) Shallower (more superficial to the globe) ( Option A ) Indications Cataract surgery, vitrectomy Cataract surgery Area of Anesthesia Primarily targets extraocular muscles Provides a wider area of anesthesia ( Option C ) Onset of Action Rapid onset Slower onset than retrobulbar Risk of Complications Higher risk of serious complications with increased risk of optic nerve injury. Lower risk of serious complications ( Option B & D ) Patient Position Supine with head turned Supine or sitting position Reference: Ocular anesthesia

questions.question: What are the two active ingredients in EMLA cream?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2.5% Lidocaine and 2.5% Prilocaine Explanation: EMLA cream contains a eutectic mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine, which work together to provide local anesthesia. EMLA Cream: Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics cream is a topical anesthetic used to numb the skin before medical procedures. Active Ingredients Contains 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine Mechanism of Action Works by blocking sodium channels in the nerve membranes, preventing nerve impulse transmission and resulting in localized anesthesia. Common Uses Primarily used for Venipuncture (insertion of IV lines) Minor surgical procedures Dermatological procedures Numbing before vaccinations Onset of Action Takes approximately 20-30 minutes to achieve effective anesthesia when applied properly. Age Considerations Generally safe for use in adults and children over 3 months old Contraindications Should not be applied to broken, inflamed, or infected skin. Caution in patients with a history of hypersensitivity to local anesthetics. Side Effects Common side effects may include skin irritation, redness, or erythema at the application site. Reference: EMLA cream EMLA cream

questions.question: A 50 year old female patient is undergoing a minor surgical procedure on her left forearm using intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) for pain control. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops seizures and exhibits signs of cardiovascular instability. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step for this patient?

options.D: Give an additional bolus of lidocaine

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Initiate lipid emulsion therapy Explanation : Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA): Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA), also known as a Bier block , is a technique that provides local anesthesia to a specific region of the body, typically an extremity, through intravenous administration of a local anesthetic. Indications Suitable for minor surgical procedures on the upper or lower extremities (hand surgeries, forearm procedures, and foot surgeries). Used when general anesthesia is not necessary and for patients with contraindications to other forms of anesthesia. Anesthetic Agents Commonly used local anesthetics include lidocaine (most frequent) and prilocaine. Procedure Steps Tourniquet Application: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal part of the extremity to prevent blood flow and keep the local anesthetic localized. Venous Access: Establish intravenous access in the selected limb. Administration of Anesthetic agent: Inject the local anesthetic into the IV line, typically in a volume of 40-50 mL. Tourniquet Management The tourniquet should be inflated to a pressure that is approximately 50 mmHg above systolic blood pressure. It is typically safe to keep the tourniquet inflated for 30-60 minutes; prolonged inflation can increase the risk of complications. Advantages Provides effective analgesia with minimal systemic absorption. Allows for a bloodless surgical field. Quick onset of action and ease of administration. Disadvantages and Complications Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) Can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation. Tourniquet Pain Nerve Damage Contraindications Infection at the injection site or over the tourniquet. Severe peripheral vascular disease. Patient refusal or inability to cooperate. Lipid Emulsion Therapy Used as a treatment for Local anesthesia systemic toxicity, acts by sequestering the local anesthetic from circulation and mitigating toxic effects. Administer a 20% lipid emulsion intravenously if toxicity occurs.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetics (LA)?

options.A: A alpha = A beta > A gamma = A delta > B > C
options.B: B > A alpha = A beta > A gamma = A delta > C
options.C: A gamma = A delta > A alpha = A beta > B > C
options.D: A gamma = A delta > B > A alpha = A beta > C

questions.explanation: the following order of susceptibilities to LA : A gamma = A delta > A alpha = A beta > B > C Local anesthetics block nerve conduction by inhibiting sodium channels. Small, myelinated fibers (like A gamma and A delta) are more susceptible than larger, myelinated fibers (A alpha and A beta). Unmyelinated C fibers are the least susceptible , while B fibers fall between A and C fibers. Susceptibility of nerve fibres to Pressure : A > B > C Susceptibility of nerve fibres to Hypoxia : B > A > C Controversial: Nerve fibre most susceptible to LA: As per Katzung Pharmacology 16th edition page no. 728- B=C>A delta>A gamma>A beta>A alpha As per Ganongs Physiology 26th edition page no. 93- C>B>A Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7808030
